definitions: think deeply or focus one's mind for a period of time in silence
engage in mental exercise such as concentration on breathing or repetition of a mantra for relaxation
examples: She likes to meditate on life's big questions before bed
The philosopher would meditate for hours on the nature of reality
Many people meditate daily to reduce stress and anxiety levels
The monks meditate every morning in the temple courtyard

definitions: blend or combine things so they become a harmonious mixture or single unit
lay down a combination of cards for points in certain card games
examples: The chef melded different spices to create a unique flavor profile
Their styles meld perfectly to create beautiful collaborative artwork
He melded three queens to score points in the rummy game
Players must meld their cards before the round ends completely

definitions: become soft sweet and mature especially through aging or ripening over time
make or become less harsh severe or extreme in character attitude or behavior
examples: The wine will mellow after aging in oak barrels for years
These pears need time to mellow before they taste their best
His personality has mellowed considerably since becoming a father last year
The harsh lighting mellowed as the sun began to set slowly

definitions: preserve the memory of someone or something especially in a ceremony or monument
commemorate someone who has died by creating a lasting tribute or memorial
examples: The museum memorializes the historic battle with detailed exhibits and artifacts
They decided to memorialize the event with a bronze plaque
The foundation memorializes fallen soldiers through scholarships for their children
Communities often memorialize local heroes by naming streets after them

definitions: commit something to memory by learning it thoroughly so it can be recalled exactly
examples: Students must memorize all fifty state capitals for the geography test
She memorized her speech so she wouldn't need note cards
Actors memorize their lines through repeated practice and rehearsal sessions
He memorized the phone number by repeating it several times

definitions: threaten someone or something with harm danger or ruin through words or actions
be a source of danger or threat to the safety or well-being of something
examples: The bully would menace younger students after school every day
Dark clouds menaced the outdoor wedding with threats of rain
Invasive species menace the native wildlife in the national park
Rising sea levels menace coastal communities around the world

definitions: repair something that is broken or damaged to make it functional again
return to health after illness or injury through rest and recovery
examples: She learned to mend clothes from her grandmother's patient teaching
The cobbler can mend those shoes to make them like new
His broken bones will mend completely in about six weeks
Time helps mend emotional wounds after a difficult breakup

definitions: make the characteristic crying sound of a cat especially to communicate needs
examples: The hungry cat would meow loudly outside the kitchen door
Kittens meow to get their mother's attention when they need help
My cat meows every morning at exactly six o'clock for breakfast
The stray cat began to meow when it saw people approaching

definitions: promote the sale of goods through advertising display and sales techniques in retail
examples: The store merchandises seasonal items prominently near the entrance display
Companies merchandise their products through social media influencers these days
They merchandise the new toy line with colorful displays and demonstrations
Retailers merchandise clearance items to make room for new inventory

definitions: combine or cause to combine to form a single entity from separate parts
join a line of moving traffic by gradually entering from another lane
examples: The two companies will merge to create a larger corporation next year
These small streams merge to form a mighty river downstream
Drivers must merge carefully when the highway lane ends ahead
Please merge left to avoid the construction zone up ahead

definitions: fit together or combine well to work effectively as coordinated parts
engage gear teeth or parts so they lock together and operate smoothly
examples: Their personalities mesh perfectly which makes them great business partners
The new employee's skills mesh well with our team's current needs
The gears must mesh properly for the machine to operate correctly
Make sure the teeth mesh completely before engaging the clutch

definitions: process substances through chemical changes in living organisms to maintain life and growth
examples: The liver metabolizes alcohol at approximately one drink per hour
Some people metabolize caffeine faster than others due to genetics
Plants metabolize carbon dioxide during photosynthesis to produce oxygen naturally
Your body metabolizes food into energy through complex chemical processes

definitions: make a soft high-pitched cry like that of a cat or seagull
examples: The tiny kitten would mew pitifully when left alone too long
Seagulls mew as they circle above the fishing boats
The newborn kittens mew constantly until their mother returns to them
You can hear gulls mew in the distance near the harbor

definitions: photograph documents or images onto film at greatly reduced size for storage
examples: Libraries microfilm old newspapers to preserve them for future generations
The archives microfilm rare manuscripts to protect the fragile originals
Government agencies used to microfilm important records before digital storage
They microfilm historical documents to save space in storage facilities

definitions: cook or heat food quickly using electromagnetic waves in a microwave oven
examples: You can microwave leftovers for a quick and easy dinner tonight
Don't microwave metal containers as they can cause dangerous sparks
She microwaves her coffee when it gets cold during long meetings
The instructions say to microwave on high for three minutes

definitions: move from one region or habitat to another according to seasons or conditions
transfer data or systems from one computing environment to another
examples: Birds migrate south for winter to find warmer weather and food
Many workers migrate to cities seeking better employment opportunities
The company will migrate all data to cloud servers next month
We need to migrate our website to a more reliable hosting platform

definitions: become affected with mildew fungus that grows in warm damp conditions
examples: Clothes will mildew if left damp in the washing machine overnight
The bathroom walls began to mildew due to poor ventilation
Books stored in basements often mildew from excess moisture over time
Leather shoes can mildew in humid climates without proper care

definitions: act out a story or express ideas using only gestures without words
imitate someone's actions or manner especially to entertain or mock them
examples: Street performers mime invisible walls to entertain passing crowds downtown
The actor had to mime climbing stairs in the theater performance
Children love to mime their teachers behind their backs at school
She would mime her boss's mannerisms to make coworkers laugh

definitions: imitate someone's actions speech or mannerisms especially for entertainment or mockery
take on the appearance or characteristics of something else in nature
examples: Comedians often mimic famous politicians to get laughs from audiences
Young children mimic their parents' behavior without realizing it
Some butterflies mimic poisonous species to avoid being eaten by predators
The synthetic material mimics the texture and appearance of real leather

definitions: cut up food especially meat into very small pieces with a knife or machine
walk with short quick steps in an affected delicate manner
examples: Mince the garlic finely before adding it to the pasta sauce
The recipe calls for you to mince one pound of beef
She would mince across the room in her high heels carefully
The actor minced onto stage portraying an overly refined character

definitions: move around and talk to other people at a social event to make connections
examples: Guests mingle during the cocktail hour before the wedding reception begins
She loves to mingle at parties and meet interesting new people
The host encouraged everyone to mingle rather than stay in groups
Business professionals mingle at networking events to make valuable contacts

definitions: reduce something to the smallest possible amount degree or extent
examples: We need to minimise costs while maintaining quality standards
Good design should minimise user confusion and maximize ease of use
The company works to minimise its environmental impact through recycling programs
Proper planning helps minimise delays during construction projects

definitions: make coins by stamping metal in an official government facility
examples: The government mints new quarters featuring national parks each year
They mint commemorative coins to celebrate important historical events
The facility mints millions of pennies daily to meet circulation demands
Countries mint their own currency to control money supply

definitions: cause to become stuck in soft wet ground that hinders movement
involve someone or something in a difficult or problematic situation
examples: Heavy trucks often mire in the muddy construction site after rain
The car mired in the swamp when we took the wrong turn
The company mired itself in legal troubles through poor decisions
Don't mire yourself in office politics by taking sides

definitions: behave in an improper or unprofessional way especially in a position of responsibility
examples: The officer was fired for misconducting himself during the investigation
Teachers who misconduct themselves face serious professional consequences
The CEO misconducted company funds leading to criminal charges
Athletes who misconduct during games receive penalties and fines

definitions: fail to fire or explode correctly when triggered in weapons or engines
fail to produce the intended result or work as planned
examples: The old engine misfires when it's cold on winter mornings
The gun misfired due to a faulty firing pin mechanism
Their marketing campaign misfired and actually decreased sales significantly
The joke misfired when nobody understood the cultural reference

definitions: cause someone to have a wrong idea or impression about something through deception
examples: False advertisements mislead consumers about the product's actual benefits
The suspect tried to mislead investigators with conflicting stories
Don't let emotions mislead you when making important financial decisions
The confusing signs misled tourists trying to find the museum

definitions: match or pair things incorrectly so they don't fit or work well together
examples: Don't mismatch your socks when getting dressed in the morning
The database will mismatch records if the formatting isn't consistent
They mismatch job candidates with positions leading to high turnover
The colors mismatch badly making the room look very uncoordinated

definitions: read something incorrectly by seeing different words or meaning than intended
interpret or judge a situation person or signal incorrectly
examples: Students often misread questions when they rush through exams too quickly
I misread the directions and went to the wrong address
She misread his silence as anger when he was just thinking
Investors who misread market signals can lose money quickly

definitions: cover or become covered with a cloud of tiny water droplets
spray fine droplets of liquid onto something using a spray bottle
examples: The windows mist up when you take hot showers in winter
Morning fog would mist the valley until the sun burned through
Mist your plants daily to keep the humidity levels high enough
The gardener mists delicate seedlings twice each day

definitions: have no confidence in someone or something based on suspicion or doubt
examples: Voters increasingly mistrust politicians who break campaign promises repeatedly
Children who are lied to often mistrust adults later
Employees mistrust management after several rounds of unexpected layoffs
She learned to mistrust anyone who offered deals too good

definitions: use something in the wrong way or for the wrong purpose
examples: People often misuse antibiotics by not completing the full prescription course
Don't misuse company equipment for personal projects at home
Students who misuse library resources may lose their borrowing privileges
Some companies misuse customer data for unauthorized marketing purposes

definitions: join two pieces of material at an angle by cutting each piece at 45 degrees
examples: Carpenters miter corners when building picture frames for clean edges
You need to miter the molding for a professional looking finish
The woodworker carefully miters each piece to ensure perfect corner joints
Learn to miter baseboards properly for seamless room transitions

definitions: make something bad less severe serious or painful through specific actions
examples: Insurance helps mitigate financial losses from unexpected disasters or accidents
Trees mitigate air pollution by absorbing carbon dioxide naturally
Good planning can mitigate risks in complex construction projects significantly
Medicine helps mitigate pain allowing patients to recover more comfortably

definitions: make a long low sound expressing pain grief or pleasure
complain or grumble about something in an annoying way repeatedly
examples: Patients moan in pain while waiting for pain medication to work
The wind would moan through the old house on stormy nights
Stop moaning about the weather and enjoy your vacation time
Coworkers moan constantly about the new management policies

definitions: crowd around someone or something in an unruly aggressive excited way
examples: Fans mob celebrities when they appear at public events unexpectedly
Reporters mob politicians after controversial announcements are made
Shoppers mob stores during Black Friday sales seeking bargain deals
Seagulls mob anyone eating food on the beach boardwalk

definitions: organize and encourage people to act together for a particular purpose
prepare and organize troops or resources for active military service
examples: Activists mobilise communities to vote in important local elections
The charity mobilises volunteers to help after natural disasters strike
Countries mobilise armies when international tensions escalate dangerously
The government mobilises reserve forces during national emergencies

definitions: organize and encourage people to act together for a particular purpose
prepare and organize troops or resources for active military service
examples: Community leaders mobilize residents to clean up neighborhood parks together
The campaign mobilizes young voters through social media outreach programs
Nations mobilize military forces in response to security threats
Emergency services mobilize quickly when disasters strike populated areas

definitions: tease or laugh at someone in a scornful or contemptuous manner
make a replica or imitation of something especially to ridicule
examples: Bullies mock other students to make themselves feel more powerful
Don't mock people for trying even if they fail initially
Comedians mock politicians by exaggerating their speech patterns and gestures
The students mock their strict teacher behind her back

definitions: adapt something to modern needs or habits by updating methods or equipment
examples: The company must modernise its technology to remain competitive globally
They modernise old buildings while preserving their historical character
Schools modernise curricula to include digital literacy and coding skills
Factories modernise production lines to increase efficiency and reduce waste

definitions: adapt something to modern needs or habits by updating methods or equipment
examples: Businesses modernize their systems to improve customer service and efficiency
The military modernizes equipment to maintain technological advantages
Cities modernize infrastructure to handle growing populations and traffic
Museums modernize exhibits using interactive digital displays

definitions: adjust or regulate the strength tone or pitch of something
vary the strength tone or pitch of one's voice while speaking
examples: Engineers modulate radio frequencies to transmit clear signals over distances
The thermostat modulates temperature to maintain comfortable room conditions
Good speakers modulate their voices to keep audiences engaged and interested
Singers must modulate between different keys during complex performances

definitions: form an object by shaping soft or plastic material with hands or tools
influence the formation or development of someone's character or abilities
examples: Artists mold clay into beautiful sculptures using their skilled hands
Children love to mold play dough into different shapes and figures
Great teachers mold young minds through patience and dedicated instruction
Parents mold their children's values through example and guidance

definitions: assault or abuse someone in a sexual way especially a child or woman
examples: Anyone who molests children faces severe criminal penalties and imprisonment
The law protects victims who report those who molest them
Predators who molest others often face long prison sentences when convicted
Schools implement strict policies to prevent anyone from molesting students

definitions: shed old feathers hair or skin to make way for new growth periodically
examples: Birds molt their feathers once or twice each year naturally
Snakes molt their entire skin as they grow larger
Crabs molt their shells to accommodate their increasing body size
Pet birds often molt during seasonal changes in temperature

definitions: promote or spread something undesirable such as fear or rumors deliberately
examples: Tabloids monger gossip about celebrities to increase their sales
Politicians sometimes monger fear to gain support for policies
Don't monger hatred by spreading false information about other groups
Some media outlets monger panic during minor crisis situations

definitions: obtain exclusive control of a trade commodity or service in a market
dominate or take up all of someone's time or attention
examples: Large corporations try to monopolize markets by buying smaller competitors
Tech giants monopolize data collection through their popular platforms
Don't monopolize the conversation at dinner parties with long stories
One student shouldn't monopolize the teacher's attention during class

definitions: make the characteristic deep sound of cattle especially cows
examples: Cows moo loudly when they're hungry or calling their calves
You can hear cattle moo across the pasture at feeding time
The baby laughed when her toy cow would moo
Dairy cows moo more frequently during milking time each morning

definitions: have a second job in addition to one's regular employment typically at night
examples: Teachers often moonlight as tutors to earn extra income
He moonlights as a security guard on weekends
Many nurses moonlight at different hospitals to pay off student loans
She moonlights as a freelance writer in the evenings

definitions: secure a boat or ship in a particular place by attaching it to the shore or anchor
examples: Sailors moor their yachts carefully before the storm arrives tonight
We need to moor the boat properly at the marina dock
Fishermen moor their vessels at the harbor after each trip
Make sure to moor the houseboat securely using proper knots
